summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of Florida discussing upcoming court hearings related to Jeffrey Epstein's case. It details Epstein's potential breach of his Non-Prosecution Agreement by contesting liability in civil suits, outlines upcoming court dates, and proposes a strategy meeting among prosecutors.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the email; his legal team is arguing against liability in civil suits, which the prosecutor believes breaches his Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Judge Marra
persons.context: Presiding judge who has asked prosecutors to appear in court to address whether Epstein's defense breaches the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Michael McAuliffe
persons.context: Noted as having been given notice of a state court hearing regarding the motion to unseal the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

connections.description: Judge Marra is presiding over federal court matters related to Epstein's case and the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
McAuliffe, from the State Attorney's Office, is involved in the state court proceedings related to unsealing the Non-Prosecution Agreement concerning Epstein.

events.title: State Court Hearing on Motion to Unseal
events.description: A hearing in state court on the Palm Beach Post's motion to intervene and unseal the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Federal Court Hearing on NPA Breach
events.description: Judge Marra has asked prosecutors to appear in federal court to address whether Epstein's defense of civil suits breaches the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Epstein's Counsel Files Pleading
events.description: Epstein's legal team filed a pleading in federal court arguing that civil claims under 18 USC 2255 must be dismissed because he was not convicted of a federal offense, which the prosecutor views as contradicting the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Potential Indictment Deadline
events.description: The prosecutor notes that if Epstein is in breach of the Agreement, the government must indict him within 60 days of learning of the breach, making July 24 a deadline.

locations: 500 East Broward Boulevard, 7th Floor, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33394
keyFacts: The prosecutor believes Jeffrey Epstein is likely in breach of his Non-Prosecution Agreement because his counsel filed a pleading contesting liability in civil suits, which contradicts the agreement's terms.
Key deadlines are noted: a hearing on June 10, 2009, regarding unsealing the NPA; a federal hearing on June 12, 2009, on the breach issue; and a potential indictment deadline of July 24, 2009.
The Palm Beach Post has filed a motion to intervene in a state civil suit to unseal the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
The email indicates internal government coordination is needed to decide on providing Epstein with 'timely notice' of his breach and potential re-indictment.
